sentence: Wall Street's major averages closed only modestly higher on Monday with gains in consumer stocks offsetting heavy losses for industrial and energy shares.

Stocks were struggling to say positive into the final hour of today's trade with tax reform delays and a freefall in shares of General Electric ( GE ) causing the major market averages to lose altitude into the close.
The retreat was compounded by technical resistance at the Dow's 100-hour moving average and 50-hour moving averages for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq.
Stock futures were trading lower on Monday in sympathy with widespread selling pressure overseas as investors cashed in on recent gains, notably in Japan's Nikkei and European bourses.
General Electric ( GE ) surrendered early gains after announcing a 50% reduction in its quarterly dividend and other cost-saving measures.
The stock subsequently fell to its lowest level in more than two years.

Mitigating downside pressure on the Dow was a record high in Boeing ( BA ) after the aerospace giant was awarded a $15 billion contract from Emirates Airlines, and Home Depot ( HD ) ahead of the company's Q3 earnings that will likely reflect the positive impact on sales from Hurricanes Irma and Harvey.
Gold and silver were higher on an earlier risk-off trade, but the 10-year yield rise slightly to 2.40%.
Oil was lower despite supply pressures tied to an earthquake on the Iran-Iraq border.

Here's where the markets stood at the close:

(+) ZYME (+24.75%) Licensed tumor-fighting drugs to Johnson & Johnson's ( JNJ ) Janssen for up to $1.45 bln

(+) NVFY (+21.47%) Q3 earnings rose to $0.11 per share on $33.2 million in revenue

(+) MAT (+20.66%) -Hasbro (HAS) is reportedly interested in buying the toymaker

(-) BAA (-54.35%) Running out of funding and funding options to service debt, continue mining operations in Congo
